text: In a federated clinical workflow redesign in utilities where new ways of working are introduced and executives want adoption, what should the project manager do to evaluate impact of the project on the organization and actions needed?

options.label: assess how new processes affect teams and operations
assume the organization will absorb changes naturally
provide no training because the tool is intuitive
delay communication until after rollout

explanation: Option a is correct because impact understanding guides adoption. Option b is incorrect because without planning, adoption suffers. Option c is incorrect because lack of training risks failure. Option d is incorrect because late communication causes resistance.

text: Given a federated clinical workflow redesign in utilities where change fatigue exists and a major launch is near, which action best supports evaluate impact of the project on the organization and actions needed?

options.label: ignore feedback about readiness
identify training, support, and change champions
focus only on technical deployment
assume the organization will absorb changes naturally

explanation: Option b is correct because enablement and champions drive adoption. Option a is incorrect because feedback is key to successful change. Option c is incorrect because organizational impacts need attention too. Option d is incorrect because without planning, adoption suffers.

text: While facing a federated clinical workflow redesign in fintech where culture is shifting and support teams need readiness, what is the most effective next step to evaluate impact of the project on the organization and actions needed?

options.label: provide no training because the tool is intuitive
delay communication until after rollout
plan communications about what changes and why
ignore feedback about readiness

explanation: Option c is correct because communication supports acceptance. Option a is incorrect because lack of training risks failure. Option b is incorrect because late communication causes resistance. Option d is incorrect because feedback is key to successful change.

text: For a predictive ERP rollout in public sector where leadership is restructuring and unions and HR are involved, what should the project manager do first to evaluate impact of the project on the organization and actions needed?

options.label: focus only on technical deployment
assume the organization will absorb changes naturally
provide no training because the tool is intuitive
monitor adoption readiness and adjust rollout

explanation: Option d is correct because readiness checks reduce disruption. Option a is incorrect because organizational impacts need attention too. Option b is incorrect because without planning, adoption suffers. Option c is incorrect because lack of training risks failure.

text: In a predictive ERP rollout in consulting where culture is shifting and stakeholders are wary, what should the project manager do to evaluate impact of the project on the organization and actions needed?

options.label: coordinate with HR and operations on impacts
delay communication until after rollout
ignore feedback about readiness
focus only on technical deployment

explanation: Option a is correct because partnership ensures smooth change. Option b is incorrect because late communication causes resistance. Option c is incorrect because feedback is key to successful change. Option d is incorrect because organizational impacts need attention too.
